Please join us at the 2019 Prep the Town in Avondale and Evanston!

This summer, we will be painting 26 houses in both Avondale and Evanston as part of Paint the Town, our largest event of the year! But before we can paint‚Ä¶ we have to prep. All 26 houses need to be scraped, primed, and powerwashed so that we can hit the ground running on the big day. 

If you provide a little love, we will provide a light breakfast, lunch, and all the tools you need to get the job done. Registration is below; sign up today!

Join us on Saturday, June 8th for Paint the Town! Approximately 750 volunteers will paint the exterior of 26 owner-occupied homes in Avondale and Evanston for those who are physically and/or financially unable to do the work themselves. Can‚Äôt spend the entire day with us? Not interested in painting? No problem! We are looking for volunteers throughout the day for tasks such as serving breakfast and lunch, parking direction, volunteer check-in, lunch delivery, etc. If you are over the age of 18, you can register via this page. We do have opportunities for volunteers age 10-17, but you‚Äôll need to contact Chelsea Brown, Volunteer Coordinator at chelsea.brown@givebackcincinnati.org to register. There will be no online registration for minors. You will receive more information via email closer to the date. If you have any questions, please contact Chelsea Brown, Volunteer Coordinator at chelsea.brown@givebackcincinnati.org

Join us on Saturday, June 8th for Paint the Town! Approximately 750 volunteers will paint the exterior of 26 owner-occupied homes in Avondale and Evanston for those who are physically and/or financially unable to do the work themselves. More details, FAQs and registration below. After-party to follow event FAQs: What if I don‚Äôt have a ‚Äúteam‚Äù to paint on? No problem! Please select ‚ÄúGeneral Volunteer‚Äù from the Team dropdown menu. We will find a house for you. What should I wear?
  1. You will be given a volunteer t-shirt upon check in, but otherwise you should wear clothes you don‚Äôt mind getting paint on.
  2. Close toed shoes, no sandals or flip-flops
  3. Hat!
What about breakfast and lunch? A grab-and-go breakfast (with coffee!!) will be available during check-in/registration. Lunch will be delivered to your house. Houses will also will have snacks and water. We will also have pizza available at the after-party. Vegetarian options are available, but if you have any other dietary needs or restrictions, please plan to bring your own food. What should I bring with me?
  1. Reusable water bottle
  2. Sunscreen
  3. Hat
  4. Driver‚Äôs License (You will need this for a beer at the After Party!)
Where should I park? Volunteers will park at Walnut Hills High School, assemble in their teams and then board busses to their houses. We will email you the meeting location‚Äôs address and specific parking instructions the week of the event. Can I volunteer for only a partial day? Yes and no. Painting a house requires a full day commitment. If you are unable to paint for a full day, we have non-painting volunteer roles with various time commitments throughout the day. Please email chelsea.brown@givebackcincinnati.org for more information. Can my relative/friend that is under 18 volunteer with me? No, all painting volunteers must be at least 18 years old. There are some non-painting volunteer roles suitable for a volunteer under 18 if they have a parent or legal guardian with them.

Help us celebrate the Fourth! We are excited to be participating in this year‚Äôs Northside 4th of July Parade, and are looking for volunteers to join our parade ensemble. üòé

Volunteers will represent Give Back Cincinnati throughout the duration of the parade and pass out GBC swag to spectators along the route. A GBC tank top will be available for volunteers while supplies last. More info about parade day below! 

PARKING FOR NON-PARADE VEHICLES:

Parking is unavailable for vehicles that aren‚Äôt IN the parade at the Greater Bethlehem Temple Church; all non-parade vehicles will need to park at the McKie Recreation Center (1655 Chase Ave) and shuttle over to the Greater Bethlehem Temple Church (4781 Hamilton Ave). The shuttle runs 9:30AM until 11:30AM. 
STAGING LOT SET UP:

When you arrive at the Greater Bethlehem Temple Church‚Äôs parking lot, you will want to find Give Back Cincinnati in section RED. Our exact parade number is 78. If you have difficulties in locating us, please find a Northside 4th of July Parade volunteer and inform them that you are looking for RED 78.
OTHER DETAILS:

We will supply all volunteers with GBC tank tops to wear during the parade; however, please feel free to get festive with your accessories.
GBC volunteers will either be handing out bottle open keychains to the crowd (do not throw, be sure to hand items to the crowd), waving flags, carrying our banner, squirting water guns, blowing bubbles, or whatever other crazy things we bring along with us. This event is all about having some fun so be ready to have a blast! J
Water, sunscreen and bug-spray will be available to all volunteers in our float.
There is a port-o-let behind the shuttle pick-up, and two near the staging lot, but that‚Äôs it. Be prepared.
PARADE END:

Celebrate a successful parade at the Northside Rock ‚Äòn Roll Carnival at Hoffner Park. All GBC volunteers who participated in the parade will receive a beer on us!

 

From the Northside 4th of July Parade Facebook event:

Parade steps off at noon on Thursday, July 4th 2019. The parade starts at the northern boundary of Northside at Hamilton Avenue and Ashtree Drive and travels south on Hamilton Avenue to Hoffner Park. Roads will close approximately 10 minutes before parade start.

The mission of the Northside Fourth of July Parade is to celebrate independence and to serve as a tool for community building. Parade organizers work to invite and involve people from all corners of the community as both participants and viewers. The parade offers a way to get to know one‚Äôs neighbors through a shared light-hearted activity. Neighbors who know one another and have laughed together are more inclined to be involved and to make their neighborhood a nicer place to live. We invite everyone to join us and help celebrate the Fourth of July!

Are you interested in volunteering with Give Back Cincinnati? Come on down to Higher Gravity Crafthaus (Northside) and enjoy a free, exclusive brewery presentation and flight tasting, all while meeting and socializing with other volunteers around Cincinnati!
 
P.S. Existing members welcome üôÇ

Final Event Details: Thank you to everyone who will volunteer with us tomorrow. We will be cleaning up the waterway along Winton Woods Harbor at¬†Winton Woods Park. Event Agenda: 8:30am - 9:00am: Check-in and registration at the boat house. 9:00am - 12:00pm: Event kickoff and cleaning up trash along the Winton Woods Harbor waterway. 12:00pm: Return to dock. Event wrap up. 12:30'ish: After party at¬†Fibonacci Brewing Company. Exact time depending on when we're all wrapped up. We'll head to Fibonacci after we're finished.
Address: Winton Woods 10245 Winton Road Springfield Township, Ohio 45231 Parking: Winton Woods is providing free parking for all volunteers. Please inform the employee working at the welcome booth that you're there to volunteer at the Don't Rock the Boat event, and they will let you in for no charge. You may park anywhere near the harbor. Be Prepared! Tomorrow will be a beautiful sunny day, so please apply sunscreen. Come dressed for being in hot weather. In the unlikely event that you end up in the water, we recommend that you come dressed in clothes you won't mind getting wet and that you lock valuables like your phone, wallet, purse, etc. in your car. Remember to stay hydrated throughout the day! After Party: Our after party will be hosted at¬†Fibonacci Brewing Company, which is about a 10 minute drive from Winton Woods Park. As a thank you to our awesome volunteers, Give Back Cincinnati will buy everyone's first beer and provide lunch. Fibonacci Address: 1445 Compton Rd Cincinnati OH 45231 Parking at Fibonacci: Fibonacci has very limited parking on their property. However, there is ample parking along the street. Just be aware to avoid parking in front of No Parking signs and Bus Stops (there may be busy stops that just have a sign and no bench). Thank you to¬†Budget Dumpster for sponsoring this event. We're looking forward to volunteering with you tomorrow! ________________________________________________________________________________________

Volunteer with us for our annual waterway clean-up event: Don‚Äôt Rock the Boat, sponsored by Budget Dumpster! On Saturday, August 10, we will take to the water to clean it up by boat. This is the perfect opportunity to enjoy Cincinnati‚Äôs outdoors, give back to the environment and meet new volunteers!

Be prepared to get dirty! We recommend long pants; long-sleeved shirts, boots or sturdy, closed-toe shoes (no sandals); work gloves to protect against scratches, insects, sunscreen, etc.; and rain gear if the sky doesn‚Äôt think we have enough water. All clean-up supplies, canoes, oars and life vests will be provided to volunteers.

Check-in and breakfast will take place from 8:30 a.m. to 8:59 a.m., and we will hit the water at 9! After a good morning‚Äôs work, we‚Äôll cool down with a happy hour at a nearby watering hole (location TBD). The first round and appetizers are on us!

We are extremely grateful for Budget Dumpster sponsoring this event. Budget Dumpster is a dumpster rental service providing low-cost and effective waste removal solutions in over 150 cities across the country, including Cincinnati! Learn more about their services and community outreach at www.budgetdumpster.com/cincinnati-oh-dumpster-rental-ohio.php.

Get more in touch with your community and build your leadership skills with Cincy YP's next event in their Community Stories series: Inclusive Leadership! At this event, Cincy YP hopes to engage YPs from across the tristate to get involved in their communities through volunteerism, build their inclusion and diversity leadership skills through service learning, and help all gain a better understanding of those who make up/form the vibrant culture within their community. Cincy YP is also in need of three more volunteer speakers to share their community story! Have a story to tell? Email Renika Smiley at info@cincyyp.org for more information.

Join us for an art-themed scavenger hunt around downtown Cincinnati, starting in the heart of OTR!

Attendees must decipher clues that will take them on a tour around downtown Cincinnati that showcases the artsy side of our city. Attendees can sign up as a team of 2-4 people or arrive as individuals that will be assigned a team upon arrival. The last destination for all participants will be at Oddfellows (2014 Elm St, Cincinnati, OH 45202) for an after party!

Registration will take place from 1:30 p.m. - 1:45 p.m.

12th Street Shuffle

The Pub Crawl With a Community Twist

12 Bars Along 12th Street & 4 Breweries -¬†Supporting Give Back Cincinnati

Experience the awesome bars and restaurants around the 12th Street area from Pendleton through OTR while supporting volunteerism in Cincinnati! The second annual 12th Street Shuffle is hosted by some of your favorite breweries and bars to benefit¬†Give Back Cincinnati, an all-volunteer led nonprofit organization that engages thousands of volunteers to uplift Greater Cincinnati's communities at over two dozen community service projects each year. You and your friends will enjoy $4 drink specials for beers by¬†3 Points Urban Brewery, MadTree Brewing, West Side Brewing, and Streetside Brewery¬†at the participating bars.¬†You'll also get a chance to win some cool raffle prizes.
Registration:¬† Tickets are $12 each with proceeds benefiting¬†Give Back Cincinnati. You'll get a 12th Street Shuffle commemorative beer mug,¬†$4¬†drink specials for beers from the featured breweries, your first drink at 3 Points Urban Brewery, and a raffle entry.

Register Here on Eventbrite¬†

Online ticket sales close on Friday night, September 6th. Tickets will be sold in-person at registration at 3 Points Urban Brewery as well.
Details: Date:¬† Saturday, September 7, 2019 Time:¬† 12:00pm - 7:00pm. Check-in opens at 11:00am. Location:¬†¬†3 Points Urban Brewery¬†Pub crawl route is along 12th Street from Pendleton through OTR.
Raffle Items: One night stay at¬†21c Museum Hotel $250 gift card to¬†Richter & Phillips Two tickets on the 42-yard line to the Cincinnati Bengals vs. Jacksonville Jaguars home game on Sunday, October 20th One-year standard membership to the¬†Cincinnati Zoo Four admission tickets, four ride tickets, and a parking pass to the¬†Cincinnati Zoo

We are partnering with the Girl Scouts of Western Ohio to provide a fun day of outdoor games at Sharon Woods (Fern Hallow) for some girls scouts in the area! Volunteers will help lead teams through different "field day" activities (including Tag, Tug of War, Turtle Soccer and more!) or help manage some of the activities themselves. It will be a day of competition and good sportsmanship for all involved! All activity supplies and lunch will be provided. We will celebrate the success of the 2019 Kids Olympics games at an after-party happy hour at Envision Cinemas Bar & Grill (4780 Cornell Rd, Blue Ash, OH 45241), and the first round will be on us! FINAL EVENT DETAILS: Date: Saturday, September 13th Time: 10:00am - 2:00pm. Registration opens at 10am. The games begin close to 11am. Location: Sharon Woods - Fern Hollow | 11450 Lebanon Road | Sharonville, OH 45241
Arrival: At the front gate, volunteers must say they are here supporting the "GS Volunteer Event" or "Field Day Event." Following the event, join us for an after party at¬†Envision Cinemas Blue Ash, 4780 Cornell Rd, Blue Ash, OH 45241 (bar only). The first round is on us!

The second-annual CincySwap event is a free clothing exchange to help the community tap into the incredible fashion sense of our Queen City peers! This is a 21+ event.
¬†
So, how do you get involved? Those interested in the Swap can either bring their clothing donations to the event venue (The Woodward Theater) or drop them off prior to the event during one of our pre-event collection dates at MadTree Taproom!
¬†
Racks of clothing will be set up throughout Woodward, and a cash bar will be available throughout the day. We are also happy to bring back DJ LPete to keep the music flowing throughout the event!
¬†
Items accepted: clothing, shoes and accessories of all shapes and sizes. Goodwill will collect any surplus of clothing following the event.
----------------------
We are in need of volunteers to help staff the event starting at Noon! On the day of the event, volunteers will help with set up and tear down, keeping clothing racks stocked with new donations, and clothing checkout. Interested? Fill out the second form below!

In partnership between Cincy YP and Fuel Cincinnati, we invite you to attend the first-ever Social Innovator $3,000 Pitch Contest, celebrating Impact + Innovation in our community with a performance by Cincinnati Music Accelerator Alumni‚Äôs. During this interactive event, Cincy YP and Fuel Cincinnati seek to recognize and support innovative nonprofit ideas working to solve critical issues facing marginalized and under-resourced communities across Cincinnati. Through various presentations, the Social Innovator Pitch Contest will showcase organizations on the forefront of change--each pitching their unique ideas for a grant prize of $3,000. That's where you come in! Each member of the audience will have the opportunity to vote for their favorite idea, narrowing the competition down to the final three contestants. Schedule:
  • 5:00 - 6:30 p.m. - Cocktail Hour
  • 6:30 - 8:00 p.m. - Pitch Contest
Cincy YP and Fuel Cincinnati are both programs of Give Back Cincinnati.

On Saturday, October 26, Give Back Cincinnati is partnering with Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center's Champions program for a Halloween-themed event. With a spooky carnival atmosphere, volunteers will interact with CCHMC‚Äôs Champions program through a variety of activities, including movies, games, pumpkin painting and more! Volunteers are encouraged to wear costumes (family- and kid-friendly)! Cincinnati Children's is a latex-free facility, so we ask that you please check to make sure your costume and costume makeup do not have any latex in it before volunteering.

Join us on Saturday, November 2, for our fourth Hands-On event of the year, Happy Trails!
¬†
Volunteers will group up at Gorman Heritage Farm to help beautify and widen a path for a corn maze; remove invasive plant species; and clean up at the end of the event. Please plan to get down and dirty! Volunteers should, at a minimum wear pants; we also recommend long sleeves. Gloves and tools will be provided.
¬†
After the event, we‚Äôll head over to a local watering hole for a GBC Happy Hour!

The Cincinnati Poverty Simulation challenges participants to take a walk in the shoes of our neighbors in need--to explore poverty experientially. The objective¬†of this event is to help people better understand the realities of living in poverty, to grow in solidarity and to take action on behalf of community neighbors in need. Staff at St Vincent DePaul Oznam Center for Service Learning will help facilitate this experience, as well as provide a debrief of the experience after completion.

To celebrate Give Back Cincinnati's soon-to-be 20th Anniversary and to ring in the year 2020, we're putting on a 1920s Gatsby Party at the 20th Century Theater!
¬†
This event is a shout out to everyone we've partnered with and to each of our volunteers. We are continuously grateful for your support in furthering our mission to build today's communities and tomorrow's leaders. You truly make the Greater Cincinnati area feel like home! Now...let's party like it's 1920!
¬†
This is a 21+ event. Please bring a valid ID to enter. Admission is FREE, and your first round is on us.

Looking to capitalize on those new year resolutions, get more involved in your community, and meet some friendly faces along the way? If so, Give Back Cincinnati is the place for you!

Join us January 11th to kick off our 20th anniversary year and learn more about our mission, upcoming volunteer opportunities, and the volunteers that make it all possible. We'll have food, bowling, and as always the first round of drinks is on us. See you there!

INFORMATION

Join us for a look into Cincinnati's history. We will walk through our Native American history, historical shifts in population, Over-The-Rhine People's Movement, and the struggles of people in Over-the-Rhine over time. Topics such as hostile design, displacement, and gentrification will be covered while also uncovering ways in which neighbors have come together to fight for their rights and security, win or lose. It will be an eye-opening tour that helps people understand the root causes of poverty and homelessness in Cincinnati, and ways in which they can get involved on a personal and structural level. Afterwards, join us at Venice on Vine (1301 Vine Street, Cincinnati, OH 45202). The first round is on us!

Join us for a cultural scavenger hunt through Northern Kentucky using public transportation! Participants will decipher clues that will take them on a tour around Northern Kentucky that showcases the art, music, and culture found south of the Ohio River. Give Back Cincinnati has been a proud member of Greater Cincinnati for more than 20 years. We‚Äôre frustrated and outraged by the wrongful deaths of George Floyd, Ahmaud Aubrey, Breonna Taylor and the many others. Give Back Cincinnati has been and will continue to be committed to serving our diverse and inclusive membership. We stand together with our brothers and sisters in the Black community to help create the world in which we want to live. We can do better. We will do better. We need to do better. Simply stating that we reject racism and discrimination isn‚Äôt enough. This conversation is meant to educate community members and be a part of starting the tough conversations with ourselves and each other. Together we can make Cincinnati a better place, for everyone. ¬†The questions have been chosen from registrants who RSVP'ed before 6/10.
Our Panelists:
Council Member Jan-Michele Kearney
Cam Hardy
Means Cameron
Sgt. Anthony Mitchell
Ginger Bock
 
Moderated by:
Evan Millward

Join Give Back Cincinnati along with Magnified Giving for a creative and fun way to learn about and make an impact for nonprofit organizations in our community! Now more than ever, nonprofits doing great work in Cincinnati are in need of financial support. This event will give you an opportunity to show the work and mission of one of your favorite nonprofits in order to earn them a monetary prize through a ‚Äúgiving circle.‚Äù Participants present for 2 to 3 minutes on any local non-profit and social cause they choose. Each participant will advocate for an agency and then the group will vote on which agency receives the grant.

DETAILS

Date: Thursday, June 25th Time: 6:30pm - 9:00pm Location: Virtual (Zoom) Rules and Guidelines:
  • Please come prepared to speak on a Zoom video call (no additional visuals) for 3 minutes max on a specific nonprofit agency that could be awarded a grant. Your pitch should include a brief overview of the work of the nonprofit and their impact in the community.
  • Only one person may sign up per nonprofit. You must list which agency you will be pitching for when registering and may be asked to pick an alternative if your nonprofit is already chosen.
  • All participants who make a pitch will get to vote on the winner at the end, and there will be prizes for 1st, 2nd, 3rd, and 4th place, which will be awarded directly to the agency.

This 3 part series is a caucus for people who want to become anti-racist, anti-supremacist allies and examine their own ideas about race and racism. Our goal is to develop awareness, knowledge, and skills that will enable us to work in solidarity with others towards racial justice in our broader community. The Aspiring Anti-Racist Allies series will aim to critically explore historical and systemic constructions of whiteness as they relate to systemic racism, identify manifestations of white privilege and racism in our everyday lives, shift focus from individual instances of white privilege and racism to broader systemic understandings of white supremacy, and develop a critical, antiracist white identity, in order to effectively take action for racial justice. The 3 sessions will be comprised of the following themes:
  1. Creation of Whiteness and Socialization of Racism
  2. Why and how to have hard conversations about race as white people as well as the history and socialization of racism
    • White Identity Development
  3. Confronting white fragility and unpacking white privilege
    • Allyship, Advocacy, and Taking Action
  4. What does it mean to be an effective ally and where do we go from here
It is strongly encouraged, but not required, that participants attend all 3 sessions. Each session will be conducted in a ‚Äúparticipatory workshop‚Äù style that will include watching short video clips as a group and discussing reactions, thoughts, and experiences with other self-identified white peers via zoom. There is no need to come to any of the sessions with anything pre-prepared, other than a willingness to share, listen, and learn.   Note: signing up for any one of this event series, you will receive the zoom information for all three sessions.

"Quaranteering" is a three-part series of events that will happen in small groups from September through November. Due to COVID-19 and the nature of precautions we need to take during this time, the series is meant to engage volunteers in outdoor events in which all precautions possible will be followed. Groups of no more than 10 people will engage in beautification activities throughout Cincinnati. This allows volunteers to continue to engage in the community and with one another while still keeping safety in mind. This event specifically is a three hour beautification project at Mt. Airy Forest in which two groups of less than 10 people (red and blue teams) will help take care of our beautiful land and ensure our community members can enjoy the space. Masks are required and will be provided. We will also provide a light breakfast and water. Thank you to Budget Dumpster for sponsoring this event!

  • A light breakfast will be provided.

Rock the Boat is BACK! Give Back Cincinnati will be cleaning up the waterway along Winton Woods Harbor at Winton Woods Park. Event Agenda:
  • 8:30am - 9:00am: Check-in and registration at the boat house.
  • 9:00am - 12:00pm: Event kickoff and cleaning up trash along the Winton Woods Harbor waterway.
  • 12:00pm: Return to dock. Event wrap up.
Parking: Winton Woods is providing free parking for all volunteers. Please inform the employee working at the welcome booth that you're there to volunteer at the Don't Rock the Boat event, and they will let you in for no charge. You may park anywhere near the harbor. The event is sponsored by Alpine Water. Quick tips:
  • Be Prepared!
  • Apply sunscreen. Come dressed for being in hot weather.

  • Remember to stay hydrated throughout the day!

Join Give Back Cincinnati on March 8th at WCPO for an in-depth look at digital citizenship.

Join Give Back Cincinnati's Leadership Development committee at 10 a.m. on Saturday, April 12 at Newport on The Levee for a look at what makes individuals and teams tick, and how your unique personality profile can work best within your teams! The second installment of our leadership series dives deeper into how GBC gets things done in what some might call the "GBC Way".¬† We will begin with an examination of the individual and our personality styles to better grasp how GBC leaders work together.¬† We will conclude by diving into the gritty details of making our events uniquely GBC. Get ready for some massive spring cleaning! On Saturday, April 26 from 9 am to 2:30 pm we'll be partnering with ODOT and Keep Cincinnati Beautiful to take on a multi-site Tri-state transformation. On the day of the event, volunteers will arrive at the meeting location for their zone, then they will be¬† divided into smaller groups and will carpool or walk to their highway site.

    • I-75 near Paddock road

    • I-75 at Towne St
  • Zone 2: West End- Cincinnati Museum Center/Union Terminal, 1301 Western Ave., Cincinnati, OH. Sites include:

We also ask that you please bring a water bottle to this event. Finally, remember, safety first! You will be working next to busy highways, so please be cautious, use common sense and respect your surroundings and fellow volunteers. *Note: Everyone must fill out the online registration for this event individually so we can have a waiver on file for all participants.¬† Please do not use the event form to book multiple people.¬†

School is in Session! Join Give Back Cincinnati by enrolling in Green University on Saturday, May 10th at Imago Earth Center, an urban nature preserve and education facility sitting on 16 natural acres in Price Hill.

Just five minutes from downtown Cincinnati, volunteers will interact with one another in educational group activities meant to school them on simple, everyday sustainable practices such as green cleaning, composting and indoor gardening. ¬†At the end of the day participants will get to take home a few ‚Äúgreen‚Äù goodies of their own to put the lessons of the day into practice. Everyone will get a bottle of green cleaner and a micro garden.

Volunteers will ‚Äúgive back‚Äù to Imago by planting trees that will add to the nature preserve landscape for years to come.

Bring your boots or tennis shoes and get ready to get your hands dirty! Class is outdoors, so remember your hats, sunglasses and sunscreen. Bagels and coffee will be available at check in. Our social twist this time is unique‚Äîwe will grill out at Imago and enjoy the tranquil forest setting among friends. In the interest of conservation, volunteers are encouraged to bring their own water bottles. The event will be from 9:30 am to 1 pm.

Fuel the Fire is an event that gives you the unique opportunity to help fund Cincinnati‚Äôs newest philanthropic entrepreneurs. ¬†Guests spend the evening learning about each applicant and their project idea. Each guest will cast a vote for their favorite project, and, at the end of the evening, the project that gets the most votes is awarded a grant comprised of the evening‚Äôs ticket sale proceeds. ¬†This year's event will take place on Wednesday, May 28 at 6:30 pm at Rhinegeist Brewery. What Do I Get With my Ticket? Each guest will receive appetizers by the bite, one free drink ticket and one ballot. Interested in presenting at Fuel the Fire? Fuel Cincinnati¬Æ encourages groups and individuals seeking funds for non-profit projects to submit applications for the event. The Fuel Cincinnati¬Æ committee will pre-select and invite up to five applicants to present. Fuel Cincinnati¬Æ strives to highlight projects that are new, creative and developed by and for the region‚Äôs future leaders as well as projects that focus on one of our four concepts: community building, education, diversity and environment. To apply as a presenter for Fuel the Fire, please submit your application, available here, by Friday,¬†May 9 to fuel@givebackcincinnati.org.

post_content: More than 1,250 paint brushes, 300 rollers, 500 ladders and 30 Port-o-Poties - yep, Port-o-Potties - are teed up to be used in just a few ¬†weeks from now... and that can only mean one thing. One of Give Back Cincinnati‚Äôs largest events, Paint the Town will take place on¬†Saturday, June 7. ¬†Approximately 1,000 volunteers will ¬†converge on Latonia, KY ¬†to get the job done! Volunteers paint the exterior of owner-occupied homes for those who are physically and/or financially unable to do the work themselves. This year, 37 homeowners have been selected to have their homes painted. More details about the event will follow, but for now, registration is officially open!

Wednesday, June 18 |¬†6 to 9 pm | Clocktower Lounge in the Gallagher Student Center at Xavier University¬†

Cincinnati is currently at the center of national debate on balancing the beliefs of religious organizations against the personal rights of their employees. The city has been thrust into the middle of this debate with the release of the Cincinnati Archdiocese‚Äôs 2014 employment contract. This debate, like many similar ones being played out across the nation, are fought in the media with no communication between the sides. The connectivity of our world enables us to connect to others, but many only connect to those with similar beliefs and ideals. Ultimately, this leads to many Demonizing the Dialogue ‚Äì or attacking the other side without fully understanding it.

For our next civic engagement event, we would like to explore both sides of the issue and facilitate a healthy, productive ¬†discussion on the topic. Our goal is to bring young professionals of different backgrounds together to discuss this important issues in a healthy, productive setting. Join us on Wednesday, June 18 at the Clocktower Lounge in the Gallagher Student Center at Xavier University¬†as we delve into this debate and discuss ways to better understand ¬†the ‚Äúothers‚Äù position. Panelists will include:
  • Ken R Craycraft Jr will eloborate on the Catholic position and discuss the issue from a legal perspective.¬†A graduate of¬†Duke University School of Law, Ken Craycraft has been practicing law since 2001. ¬†Ken‚Äôs work at Shade Law Group LLC involves helping injured and aggrieved clients to resolve disputes as efficiently and with as little stress and expense as possible. He is committed to civility and collegiality in civil litigation, keeping in mind that few people want to sue or be sued, but that some disputes cannot otherwise be resolved.¬†Prior to his law career, Ken was a university professor, teaching Moral Theology at¬†St. Mary‚Äôs University in San Antonio, Texas. He holds a Ph.D. in Theology from¬†Boston College, as well as master‚Äôs degrees from the¬†University of Cincinnati¬†and Cincinnati Christian University.¬†¬†His academic work concentrated on the intersection between theology and political theory, as well as the role of religion in American law and public life. In addition to dozens or articles and reviews in such publications as Crisis, First Things, Review of Politics, Theology Today, and the Journal of Law and Religion, he is the author of¬†The American Myth of Religious Freedom
 
  • Greg Landsman will talk about the challenge of secular and faith based¬†initiatives in a pluralistic society.¬†Greg Landsman currently serves as the Executive Director for The Strive Partnership, an education consortium of local providers and funders working together to improve academic achievement along the education continuum ‚Äì kindergarten readiness, proficiency scores, graduation rates, and postsecondary enrollment and completion rates ‚Äì in Cincinnati, Newport and Covington. Before joining Strive, Landsman was appointed Director of the Governor‚Äôs Office of Faith-Based and Community Initiatives by Governor Ted Strickland in October of 2007.
 
  • Bill Lonneman will talk about his¬†experience in¬†helping creating¬†dialogues as bridges of¬†understanding between faith groups.¬†In the wake of¬†public revelations about the sexual abuse scandal¬†in the Catholic church, Bill Lonneman attended the original¬†Boston gathering of Voice of the Faithful (VOTF) in 2002.¬†¬†He returned home¬†and¬†became¬†one of the founders¬†of the Greater Cincinnati chapter of VOTF; the next¬†year he was fired from his Pastoral Ministry position at a local parish.¬† In 2004 he completed his MA in Theology at Xavier. Since 2006, in his capacity as Advancement Coordinator¬†for Franciscans Network,¬†he has helped to organize Muslim-Christian dialogues in the city.¬†Bill¬†is a member of the nursing faculty at the College of Mount St. Joseph and lives in College Hill with his wife, Julie.
 
  • Mary Kay Connolly will speak about the use of service learning as a methodology for bridging the gap between sacred and secular interests.¬†Mary Kay is the Director of Service Learning as a part of the Myerson Service Learning Initiative on behalf of Chidren‚Äôs Inc. ¬†Mary Kay received her degree in Counseling and Social Work from Xavier University. ¬†In 2012-2013, over 26,000 students investigated an issue, designed solutions or supports to address a need, acted through serving others, reflected upon their service impact and then demonstrated their increased knowledge or 21st Century skills. This initiative demonstrates that collaboration can work between secular and sacred education through the pedagogy of service learning.

Gather your team of three to four and prepare for a scavenger hunt that combines wits, physical challenges and ‚Äì at the end ‚Äì a beverage or two. Join us as we take to the streets of OTR and Downtown for another GBC Challenge on Saturday, June 21. Every team member must sign up separately

As always, team costumes are optional, but encouraged. Whether you‚Äôre a seasoned Cincinnatian or a Queen City newbie, this scavenger hunt has something for you. ¬†Sign up below!

Buckle Up Cincinnati, a new three-day, six-stage music bash on the banks of the Ohio River, is looking for volunteers! Featuring a stellar lineup from the heartland, acts will include Alabama, Willie Nelson, Alison Krauss and Union Station, and The Band Perry.

To sign up, go to the Buckle Up Festival Volunteer page. In the ‚Äútell us why you would be a good volunteer‚Äù section, type ‚ÄúGive Back Cincinnati.‚Äù After you submit the form, you will be sent an email on how to sign up for shifts. Positions include working at the staff gate checking in vendors and staff, working the entrance gate checking tickets and putting on wristbands, and working with the festival‚Äôs Clean Team to make sure people recycle as much as possible.

post_title: The Forgotten Underbelly of Sex, Human Trafficking, and Cycles of Violence Against Women and Children
post_content: For our next Civic Engagement session, we‚Äôll be taking on a very serious topic that often goes ignored-- the forgotten underbelly of sex, human trafficking, and cycles of violence against women and children.¬† Please join us on Wednesday, October 1 at 6 pm at the First Unitarian Church of Cincinnati for a thought- provoking and eye-opening discussion on a part of our society that is often not discussed and marginalized. Representatives from Destiny Rescue - On the ground workers against the Child Sex Trade, Sex and Pornography Addiction Counselors from Counseling Alliance, City of Cincinnati Police, Lighthouse Youth Services, and a Sociologist and Spiritual leader of the Cincinnati Muslim Community on Research on Pornography and Attitudes Towards Women will serve as panelists. Register below.

Give Back with the Future | Saturday, November 8 | 9:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. | Newport Intermediate School On Saturday, November 8, GBC volunteers will pair up with Boys & Girls Club‚Äôs ‚ÄúKeystone Club‚Äù teens in another Give Back with the Future project. Personal stories of hope and encouragement will will serve as the inspiration for the day‚Äôs service project. Volunteers and teens will be involved in creating a ‚ÄúHOPE‚Äù boxes, to be filled with items such as bookmarks, shrinky dink jewelry, and more. The ‚ÄúHOPE‚Äù boxes will be donated to the students of Newport Intermediate School who demonstrate improved academic performance throughout the school year. This project came to the attention of GBC through a connection with Faces without Places (FwP), a social service organization that provides educational and enrichment programming, school transportation and supplies, and other specialized services to thousands of children and youth experiencing homelessness each year in Greater Cincinnati and Northern Kentucky. Newport Intermediate School is one of many schools in the area who benefit each year from FwP services. Statistically, 89% of the students at Newport Intermediate receive free or reduced lunch, with 12% identified as experiencing homelessness. The school also performed the 2nd lowest in the State of Kentucky ranking 729 out of 730 elementary schools. But through hard work and taking measures in focusing on giving their students ‚ÄúHOPE‚Äù this past year they are now considered a Kentucky High-Progress School demonstrating more academic growth compared to other elementary schools in the state. The ‚ÄúHOPE‚Äù boxes that GBC volunteers & Boys & Girls Club teens will be create during Give Back with The Future will serve to help Newport Intermediate School continue to improve academically by helping them continue to inspire, motivate, and instill HOPE to among their well-deserved students. Saturday, March 21 | 10am - noon The heroin epidemic is currently sweeping Greater Cincinnati, impacting our lives and our city. Join us at the Westwood Library for a panel discussion¬†with the leaders on the frontlines of the fight, including:

Carol Baden (Founder - Community Recover Project; Founder - People Advocating Recovery Southwest Ohio)¬†Since founding Community Recovery Project and People Advocating Recovery Southwest Ohio, Carol has¬†worked full-time to assist those affected by the opioid epidemic. Both¬†organizations were founded to bridge the existing gaps, facilitate relationships and dialogue amongst the many entities involved in this public health crisis. Prior to founding both organizations, Carole¬†worked as a medical professional in inpatient and outpatient settings for 30 years.

Josh Arnold (Vice President,¬†Talbert House) Josh has a Bachelors Degree from the University of Tennessee in Criminal Justice and a Master‚Äôs Degree in Community Counseling from Xavier University. Josh is a Licensed Professional Counselor in Ohio and in his 16 years with Talbert House has worked with adults with severe and persistent mental illness, substance abuse and has overseen Talbert House‚Äôs Youth and Adolescent Services. He currently leads the agency‚Äôs Court and Corrections Service line and is a graduate of Executive Curriculum for Emerging Leaders and Leadership Cincinnati.

Angela Vance (LGBTQ Liaison Officer, Cincinnati Police Department)¬†Angela was born and raised in Cincinnati. She graduated from Mariemont¬†High school prior to joining the Air Force in 1987 where she was a Law Enforcement¬†Specialist. In 1990, Angela joined the Cincinnati Police Department where she is¬†currently employed as one of Cincinnati's finest policewomen. Throughout her career, she's been assigned to¬†various units including the Firearms Training Unit and the Police Academy.¬†Her new role in the department is the LGBT Liaison for the City of Cincinnati¬†and it's citizens.

Jon Harmon (Legislative Director,¬†Cincinnati City Councilman Chris Seelbach) Originally from Orange County, Jon moved to Cincinnati to attend the University of Cincinnati and quickly fell in love with the city. He made a career change from non-profit arts management to politics and government when Chris Seelbach asked him to manager his campaign for city council. After helping Chris win a seat on Cincinnati City Council, Jon joined Councilman Seelbach‚Äôs staff at City Hall.¬†Jon‚Äôs passions for the city are reviving the pedestrian character of our neighborhoods that led to our great business districts, growing local businesses, especially family-owned shops and finding ways to promote more environmentally friendly living in Cincinnati.

¬†Afterwards, the conversation will continue at the The Public House.

This year, we'll be performing litter cleanup and general landscaping, with lunch provided by¬†Currito. It‚Äôs time to show Cincinnati some GBC muscle. post_content: When:¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Thursday, April 16 Time:¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 6:30 PM ‚Äì 8:30 PM Location:¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Northwestern Mutual, 3805 Edwards Rd, Cincinnati, OH, 7th Floor Conference Room   Welcome to our new and returning Team Leads!¬† Our goal with the Westwood¬†Paint the Town Team Lead Kickoff is to provide you everything you need to be successful in 2015. The next GBC leadership development session is Saturday, April 18th. The second installment of our leadership series dives deeper into how GBC gets things done in what we some might call the ‚ÄúGBC Way‚Äù.¬†¬†Our agenda is straightforward. We'll start with an ice breaker to get you up and moving, and networking too. Then we'll dive into your individual styles, talk about how your personality traits (and those of others) function within teams. We will also walk through the nuts and bolts of GBC events. Pre-Work is required for this event!¬†Please complete and bring with you your individual DISC personality profile. What's a DISC profile? It's a way to discover what drives you. And you can do it in 15 minutes. Just hop on over to the Tony Robbins website to take a short test. You will have to sign up for Tony's emails, but you can unsubscribe at any time. Here's the link:¬†http://www.tonyrobbins.com/disc-profile/¬†If you took this test for last year's session, there's no need to take it again. Just bring your results with you. Breakfast will be provided.¬† Location is Newport on the Levee Community Center. Please plan to attend from 10 a.m. to 12:30 Please share this with your committees. Thanks, The Leadership Development Committee

post_title: GBC Reunion Weekend: Saturday Hands-On Activity
post_content:
Host a Give Back Cincinnati reunion without a hands-on event? Inconceivable! For GBC First 15, we're doing what we do best: getting down and dirty by making a visible impact on the community. We're going back to where it all began -- Norwood Middle School -- for a series of improvement projects to prepare the school for the start of the academic year. We'll mulch, landscape, paint and beautify as a way of saying, "Welcome back!" to students and staff. Volunteers of all ages are welcome to participate in this event.¬†We'll have kid-friendly activities in addition to grown-up ones. Essential details:
  • 8-8:30 a.m. -- registration and breakfast
  • 9 a.m.-12 p.m. -- hands-on event
  • 12-2 p.m. -- family-friendly after party*
Please use the ticket options below to reserve your adult or child volunteer spot. Note an additional volunteer waiver will be required on the day of the event, signed by a parent or guardian¬†of each volunteer who is under the age of 18. *Don't let the term "family friendly" fool you; there will be plenty of 21-and-older fun to go around.

post_title: GBC Reunion Weekend: Family Friendly Party
post_content: Can't make the GBC Reunion Weekend hands-on event? (Or, don't feel like getting up that early/bringing the kiddos?) That's cool; join us instead for a family friendly after party at Madtree from 12 to 2 p.m.! Enjoy a beer, a couple slices of pizza and family friendly games while renewing old friendships and forging new ones. There will even be a few super cool giveaway items... so claim your spot today! Please note the after party is complimentary¬†to volunteers who participate in the hands-on event on Saturday morning. There will be a $10 fee per adult and $5 fee per child¬†for those electing to only attend the after party. Each ticket will include pizza from Catch-a-Fire pizza. Adults will get two beer tickets in addition to pizza.

Think of Sunday as the unofficial after party of GBC Reunion Weekend... a series of "come as you" pop-up events that you can join as your schedule allows. Here's the scoop:
  • 10:30 a.m. ‚Äî Casual, on-your-own¬†brunch at Crave; reservation is under Andrea Enders/Give Back Cincinnati
  • 12 to 1 p.m.¬†‚Äî *FREE* rides on Carol Ann's Carousel at Smale Riverfront Park¬†for the first 40 Give Backers to get there
  • 1 to 4 p.m.¬†‚Äî Meet-and-greet at the Give Back Cincinnati tent while¬†enjoying local art, jewelry, clothing,¬†music, food, beer and more at Second Sunday on Main
You're welcome to attend any or all of these fun events... no RSVP necessary! For the past four¬†years, the GBC Leadership Development committee has ended our training season with a panel discussion among local leaders to add value and richness to the leadership experience for our dedicated volunteers.¬† Our panels have included many talented individuals, such as Santa Ono from UC, Johnna Reeder from Redi Cincinnati, Mark Policinski from OKI, Kirk Perry from P&G and Dr. Victor Garcia from CoreChange. Since this is GBC‚Äôs 15th anniversary, we thought we'd go back to where it all began: the founders and first members of Give Back Cincinnati. Those people who brought big, bold ideas to the table and turned them into the organization you know (and love!) today. What better way to celebrate them and their legacy than to have them¬†share their own journeys and lessons learned?! The panel will be hosted at¬†Boost! meeting space at 538 Reading Road, Ste. 300,¬†on Monday, August 31 from 5:30 to 7:30 p.m. Enjoy networking with our panelists, as well as with one another, in addition to some nibbles and grown-up beverages. Our panelists include:
  1. Maggie Brennan ¬†- co-founder of Fuel Cincinnati
  2. Beth Gottfried - former membership director and co-founder of Fuel
  3. Ryan Rybolt - one of the founders of Give Back Cincinnati
  4. Joe Hansbauer ¬†- ¬†founder of Give Back Beyond
  5. Erin Klotzbach ¬†- ¬†co-founder of¬†Fall Feast
  6. Rob Porter ¬†- ¬†founder of Paint the Town

Come learn what it takes to run Give Back Cincinnati on a day-to-day basis! Join the GBC leadership development committee as we take a look at the mission, vision and values of Give Back Cincinnati, discuss what is asked of the organization's leaders and review the available positions heading into 2016. Please know that no prior leadership experience with Give Back is necessary to join and become a leader. Current and former leaders of the organization will be available to ask questions and help guide you toward committees or leadership roles that interest you most. Light refreshments will be served. When: 3 sessions: Saturday, Oct. 10th and 17th @ 10 a.m. or Wednesday, Oct. 14 @ 6 p.m. Where: Updated Location for October 14th: October 14th: Newport on the Levee Community Room A 1 Levee Way, Newport, KY 41071 Parking is available in the Newport on the Levee Garage and on-street parking is available on Monmouth and Saratoga Streets. October 17th: Wordsworth Communications 538 Reading Road, Ste. 100 Cincinnati, OH 45202 Free parking is available on Reading Road (directly in front of the building) and across the street at the Horseshoe Casino. There are parking meters on surrounding side streets and a Red Bike station at the corner of Reading and Broadway, two blocks down. What to bring: Your questions about GBC leadership, a willingness to learn more about the organization and a desire to get more involved Once you've attended or if you're unable to attend, please complete this form to inform us of¬†your specific interest in a leadership role with GBC: ¬†Leadership Application

Join us¬†on the evening of Monday, October 19 for our fourth annual¬†Fuel The Fire!

What is Fuel The Fire?

Fuel The Fire is an event that gives you the unique opportunity to help fund Cincinnati‚Äôs newest social entrepreneurs. Below is an quick overview of the event. As a guest, you'll spend the evening learning about each applicant and their project idea. You'll cast a vote for your favorite project. And at the end of the evening, the project that gets the most votes is awarded a grant comprised of the evening‚Äôs ticket sale proceeds. This year's event will take place at the MadTree Brewing Tap Room on Monday, October 19 at 6:30 PM. For more information on Fuel Cincinnati and to keep updated on the speakers go to¬†http://fuelcincinnati.org/fuelthefire

Wednesday, October 28 | 6pm - 9pm
GBC Challenge returns on Wednesday, October 28 in an all new format at the Christian Moerlein Taproom in OTR!
We'll be learning the art of fowling from Moerlein's "Commissioner of Fowling" and then play a few rounds of fowling! What is fowling you say? Fowling is what happens when you take the best of football, cornhole and bowling and create an all new sport.
Teams alternate throwing a football at the opposing teams ten pins. Like in cornhole, teams alternate throws and cycle through players.
Drinks and light bites will be served at the event.

November 7 | 8:30 am - 1pm Join us on Saturday, November 7 for Give Back with the Future! Volunteers and teens from the local YMCA will create care packages for kids and young adults battling cancer and bone marrow transplants through the Dragonfly Foundation. Register below!
This is a signup exclusively for the teen volunteers.

Thursday, November 19 | 6pm We all know there are plenty of reasons to recycle in order to preserve our earth and its natural resources, but you may know that recycling can also be fun! Join GBC at Rhinegeist as we celebrate the Art of Recycling! Attendees will have free pizza, the chance to earn free beer tickets, and learn how to waste less and use more! This interactive event will showcase artists and carpenters who use discarded items to create, design, and build something totally new. In addition, Cincinnati Recycles and the Green Umbrella Waste Reduction Action Team will present on the importance of recycling, how to properly recycle, and how easily incororate recycling into your routine. Organizations and individuals at the event will include:
  • Scrapnati
  • Building Value
  • 3R Recycling
  • Cincinnati Recycles
  • ¬†Habitat for Humanity of Greater Cincinnati ReStore
  • Kunst
  • Robert McFate Studio
  • Melissa Spencer
  • HaloMiner
  • Emily Lyn Design
  • Recyclabowls
Join us at Tostado's Grill (3500 Eastern Ave, Cincinnati, OH 45226) on Tuesday, December 1 from 6-8pm to have a few drinks, enjoy some food, sing karaoke and learn more about Give Back Cincinnati!

Tis' the season for the annual Give Back Cincinnati Holiday Party!

To help us celebrate the end of our 15th year of service, we're taking over the 20th Century Theater in Oakley. Register now to eat, drink and be merry with GBC!

EAT: Pizza and lights bites will be provided
DRINK: GBC will buy a drink for the first 200 people through the door
BE MERRY: Music from DJ Diamond and other festive activities

You've all been good this year, so we're planning on giving everyone a little present and raffling off some special prizes.

See you on December 10, it's the most wonderful time for a beer!

Step right up and ring in the First Midnight of 2016 at Cincinnati‚Äôs main event. Join us New Years Eve from 10pm - 2am, on the Pavilion Level of Horseshoe Casino Cincinnati for the ‚ÄúGreatest Party on Earth‚Äù. Where: Horseshoe Casino Cincinnati, Pavilion Level When: December 31st 10pm - 2am Visit firstmidnight.com for tickets and more information. A portion of proceeds will benefit Give Back Cincinnati.

Saturday, January 16 | 9am - 2pm At Give Back Cincinnati, we kick off every year by going back to where it all began - Back to School! Join us on Saturday, January 16¬†at Winton Woods Medical and Health Center (5275 Winneste Avenue, Cincinnati, 45232). We will be partnering with Cradle Cincinnati, a group that focuses on reducing infant mortality in Cincinnati, to give the health center a fresh new coat of paint. This health center is one of 23 in the city that provides care to women and children in need or on public assistance. Volunteers will be painting the lobby, waiting room, hallways, doors, meeting spaces, screening rooms and more. As always, we'll celebrate another successful event at a local watering hole!

Join us on Saturday, January 23, 5-9pm ¬†for Fountain Square's Throwback Skate! We'll be skating to your favorite 80s tunes, and for every flier that's collected, GBC will get $2!¬†Print out this¬†flier, and we'll see you there!

Give Back Cincinnati's Leadership Committee invites you to attend the first leadership training session of 2016! We'll share more about¬†who we are as an organization, what we do¬†and¬†why we make the choices we make, how we execute our evets and what we expect of our committee members and more. Who Should Attend:¬†Anyone who is currently involved or would like to be involved in a Give Back Cincinnati planning committee When: Saturday, February 6, 2016 9:30¬†a.m. to 12:0 p.m., followed by networking at Brother's Bar & Grill Where:¬†Newport on the Levee Community Room A Located on the lower level next to Gameworks Please note there's construction around the Levee, so allow a little extra time for parking! What's on the Agenda:¬†The Leadership Committee will supply¬†breakfast and liquid gold (aka coffee). We'll then dive into our core agenda, which¬†will cover GBC operations¬†in three parts: Give Back Cincinnati 101, how to run a GBC event¬†and leadership expectations. After you provide some feedback, we'll head to a local watering hole to continue the discussion. What to Bring:¬†You may want to take notes, so bring whatever device you are comfortable with (including good ol' fashioned pen & paper). What You'll Get:¬†You'll be provided with a hard copy of our Give Back Cincinnati: Nuts and Bolts guide, which we will send electronically following the event. Our goal is also to provide a forum for idea sharing, meeting your fellow GBCers and learning a few tricks for flawlessly executing GBC events. Questions:¬†Please email Adam.Pulskamp@givebackcincinnati.org if you have questions.

Wednesday, February 17 Join us on Wednesday, February 17 at Neon's to learn more about Give Back Beyond Cincinnati and opportunities to get involved. We'll be on the second floor, so grab yourself a drink and meet us upstairs at 6pm to learn more about how you can get involved! post_title: Refugees in Cincinnati: The Local Impact on a Global Crisis
post_content:
Did you know there are over 12,000 refugees living and working in Greater Cincinnati and hundreds more arriving each year? Who are they? What are the challenges they face? How can you help? Come hear the answers first hand!¬†This event is a chance to increase your cultural competence, enjoy food from refugee-owned businesses, and directly support Cincinnati‚Äôs refugee population.

We'll be hosting a panel discussion from 10am - 12pm. We'll follow this up with a¬†choose your-own-adventure... stay to sort donations for local refugees, or head directly to Yat Ka Mein, a refugee-owned business on Madison Road, to continue the conversation¬†over lunch with a few of the panelists. Those that choose to stay and sort donations will join the after party at Yat Ka Mein at 1pm!

This event will take place at Red Cross - Cincinnati Chapter on Saturday, March 12.

Join the madness!

post_title: Give Back Cincinnati Leadership Event #2: Your Leadership Styles
post_content: Join Give Back Cincinnati's Leadership Development committee at 10:00¬†a.m. on Saturday, April 2 ¬†for a look at what makes individuals and teams tick, and how your unique leadership skills¬†can work best within your teams! The second installment of our leadership series dives deeper into individual and team dynamics to better grasp how GBC leaders work together. Once we've nailed down your individual leadership style and needs, we'll role play different ways you as an individual can influence team dynamics -- and give your committee members the experience they're looking for! Pre-Work is required for this event!¬†Please complete and bring with you your individual DISC personality profile. What's a DISC profile? It's a way to discover what drives you... and you can do it in 15 minutes. Just hop on over to the Tony Robbins website to take a short test. (You will have to sign up for Tony's emails, but you can unsubscribe at any time.) If you took this test for a previous session or leadership development training, feel free to bring your results with you - or take the test again to see how your results may have changed! post_title: Better Together: Building a Cincinnati That Works for Everyone
post_content:
We have all noticed Cincinnati‚Äôs incredible growth over the past few years. While these changes have benefited¬†many, several community members have struggled as a result. What lessons have we learned from the current model of growth? What new understandings can we utilize to assist in our redevelopment of the city's urban areas moving forward?

Join us on August 6th at 10am ¬†at Pallet23 in Northside (3932 Spring Grove Ave, Cincinnati, OH 45223) for a¬†panel discussion featuring¬†NKU professor Dr. Christopher Wilkey, who works on documenting stories from marginalized community members. Also featured,¬†Vice Mayor David Mann, and Kevin Wright, President of the Walnut Hills Redevelopment Foundation.

During this discussion, our panel will discuss the achievements and shortcomings of recent urban development in Cincinnati and the best way to invest in communities that work for everyone.

We can continue the conversation during the after party at Boswell's (1686 Blue Rock St, Cincinnati, OH 45223)!

Join us Saturday, August 13, 9AM ‚Äì 1PM for the Backyard Bash at the Village! We'll be playing backyard games and¬†casino games with the seniors at St. Paul Village in Madisonville. We'll follow that with a cookout for lunch! It's going to be a blast, rain or shine, we'll move indoors if the weather is bad. Come join us for games and fun - then we'll move on to MadTree Brewing for an awesome after-party! See you there! More details will be added as they become available.

This is Give Back Cincinnati's largest annual fundraiser, so come and grab a beer from us on Cincinnati's favorite holiday. See you at Fountain Square on Monday, April 3. Go Reds!

Earth Day Spruce Up

Volunteer with Give Back Cincinnati on Earth Day at Imago Earth Center in Price Hill for our second Hands On event for the year!  Our volunteer project will consist of working on the trails throughout Imago's grounds, which will include evening out and creating trails, along with laying limestone and mulch on the trail paths that we are working on.  Additionally, we will be doing weeding and planting in the gardens on the grounds.  Since it's Earth Day, we will do a clean up of Imago's grounds after we're finished with the project (time permitting). In classic Give Back Cincinnati fashion, we will have an after party happy hour at Incline Public House to celebrate the success of our Earth Day volunteer project and to help volunteers meet some new friends!  

Earth Day Volunteer Project Details:

  • Date: Saturday, April 22.
  • Time: Check-in with light breakfast provided 8:30 - 9:00 AM, project starts at 9:00 AM, break for lunch between 11:30 AM - 12:00 PM (lunch provided), targeted event wrap-up at 2:00 PM.
  • Location: Imago Earth Center - 700 Enright Ave. Cincinnati, OH 45205. 
  • Parking: Street parking. 
  • After Party: Incline Public House
About Imago Earth Center: Imago's mission is to foster a deeper harmony with Earth by providing educational experiences, creating opportunities for discussion and community building, and conserving natural areas. Imago was founded over 30 years ago by Jim and Eileen Schenk two social workers - with the purpose of reconnecting people to the natural world.  Through the years Imago has brought to the Cincinnati region innovative ideas on living sustainably. Among many accomplishments, Imago has:
  • Presented 7 major conferences on Ecology and Spirituality, with over 2200 participants.
  • Preserved 23 acres of urban forest, 16 acres of which are open to the general public at the Earth Center, an urban nature preserve and education facility.
  • Presented environmental education programs to over 50,000 students from area schools.
  • Enriched the lives of over 200 youth through our nature summer camps.
  • Collaborated closely with public schools, social service agencies, community organizations, businesses, funders, and other environmental educators to provide an exciting array of programs and services to the Greater Cincinnati community
  • Engendered 4 different nonprofit organizations serving communities and the environment in Greater Cincinnati (Western Wildlife Corridor, Price Hill Will, Price Hill Land Foundation, Enright Ridge Urban Eco-Village
  • Twice been voted "Best Friend of the Environment" and once the best "Urban Greenspace" by the readers of CityBeat.
  • Demonstrated a model for community-wide environmental change that is educational, collaborative, and fun!

On Saturday, May 13th, we'll gather a group of awesome volunteers to get the homes in Dayton/Bellevue ready for painting! We'll be scraping, power washing and otherwise getting the homes ready for Paint the Town! Register to volunteer here. Stay up-to-date on Paint the Town info at http://paintthetowncincinnati.org/! Experience one of Cincinnati's most promising up-and-coming neighborhoods! You'll start your adventure at Brew House at 2 p.m., where you'll split into teams of new and old friends! Through this scavenger hunt, you'll play games and win prizes at the bars, restaurants and shops that define Walnut Hills. After the event, eat, drink, and socialize with key people in the community at the finish line: Video Archive.

Fuel The Fire is an event that gives you the unique opportunity to help fund Cincinnati‚Äôs newest social entrepreneurs. Below is an quick overview of the event.
  As a guest, you'll spend the evening learning about each applicant and their project idea. You'll cast a vote for your favorite project. And at the end of the evening, the project that gets the most votes is awarded a grant comprised of the evening‚Äôs ticket sale proceeds. This year's event will take place at the MadTree Brewing Tap Room May 23rd at 6:30 PM.

I want to attend and support!

How much does it cost to attend? $30 at the door, $20 in advance What do I get with my ticket? Each guest will receive appetizers provided by Catch-A-Fire Pizza, one drink ticket, and a vote. Register For Fuel the Fire Here!

Hello Paint the Town 2017 volunteers! Thank you for spending your Saturday with us--we greatly appreciate it and couldn't complete this amazing feat without each and every one of you! Your time and dedication will brighten up 30 houses in 2 different neighborhoods, making a positive impact for years to come. Registration will take place in the Dayton High School gym, starting a 7:45 a.m. We'll have brand spankin' new t-shirts, water bottles, and breakfast provided. Lunch and all painting materials will be provided at the houses. NOTE: Volunteer registration is still open for this weekend! Click here to be redirected to our volunteer sign-up.

Schedule of Events

7:45 a.m. to 8:30 a.m. Team sign-in and breakfast 8:30 a.m. Announcements  8:45 a.m. Volunteers dismissed to buses 4 p.m. Painting concludes Following After Party!

Everything You Want to Know & More

Where is registration?  Dayton High School Gymnasium   200 Greendevil Lane Dayton, KY 41074 If you pre-registered for a corporate team, go directly to your corporate team table to sign in.
If you registered as a general Give Back Cincinnati volunteer, sign in at the main registration table.
 
Where do I park? There is not a designated parking lot. Paint the Town Parking volunteers will be in neon vests and directing traffic to recommended parking areas. Please see a detailed parking diagram below.
How do I get to my house? Buses will transport volunteers to the houses for the day. When you sign in with your team, your bus number will be on the registration sheet. There is limited parking at every house and we try to be respectful of our neighbors; please do not drive yourself directly to the houses. What should I bring with me? Wear clothes that you are not afraid to get dirty. T-shirts will be provided for all volunteers. Your shoes should be sturdy with closed toes (no flip-flops) and you may want to bring a hat, sunglasses, sunscreen or bug spray. Please leave your valuables at home. We'll have all of the painting supplies you'll need, but feel free to bring your favorite paint brush or roller if you feel inclined to do so. What if I get hangry? Lunch will be delivered to the house you are painting between noon and 1 p.m. Chick-fil-A sandwiches, Grippo's chips and cookies will be provided for lunch. Vegetarian option is available upon request. If you have special dietary needs, we recommend bringing a bagged lunch. How are we celebrating? After a hard day of work please join us for Give Back Cincinnati‚Äôs Paint the Town After Party! This will take place at Gil Lynn Park next to Dayton High School. There will be music, food, and of course beer. Bring your ID, you will need a wristband to drink. You will receive two food tickets and two beer tickets. Additional beers can be purchased for $2. What if it rains? Regardless of the forecast, rain or shine, please plan on showing up in the morning for registration. Any changes to the schedule due to weather will be determined at registration.

How do you tackle difficult conversations? It starts with understanding three stories: yours, theirs and the "somewhere in-between." And that's exactly what we'll discuss in this new for 2017 leadership development session of the year: Having Difficult Conversations. The second leadership development session of the year will help leaders better serve their committees, the Give Back Cincinnati organization and even their professional lives by sharing common scenarios that make leadership difficult -- whether it's a team member who isn't pulling their weight or another volunteer who makes collaboration challenging. We'll also provide tips for how to surface and solve these issues in a healthy, productive manner... followed by some hands-on training. Afterwards, we'll head over to Brothers for a beer and continued conversation.  When: Saturday, June 17 10 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. Where: Newport on the Levee, Community Room B Who: This session is open to all team leads and their committees

The parade starts at 11am.  You are more than welcome to watch the parade and then join us at the Family Fun Zone at the festival afterwards!  Parking: Cincinnati Pride Festival has allocated a set number of parking spots for volunteers for the day.  As a backup option, you can park at Jack Casino and ride the streetcar down to The Banks.  The festival will be a short walking distance from that stop.  Cincinnati Pride also has a selected parking vendor.  [mc4wp_form id="8578"]

post_title: Panel: Leadership in a Diverse World
post_content:
Leadership in a Diverse World

Cincinnati is an increasingly global city, and as such, must intentionally encourage, celebrate and seek out diversity. Whether it's gender or sexuality, racial or cultural, educational or socioeconomic, we'll acknowledge the strides the city -- and by extension, Give Back Cincinnati -- has made in become a more diverse and welcoming place. And we'll also take a candid look at ways we can continue to address and advance leadership to build a more diverse and inclusive world. 
Our panelists will include: 
-  William Gipson, P&G R&D President and Chief Diversity Officer
-  Mary Stagaman, Senior Inclusion Adviser at Cincinnati USA Regional Chamber
-  Eric Avner, CEO at People's Liberty
-  Chris Seelbach, Cincinnati City Councilman
-  Bonnie Meyer, Director of LGBTQ Programs & Services at NKU
 
This session is open to everyone, but will also serve as the kick-off of Give Back Cincinnati's fall leadership recruitment season. Those who are currently involved in a committee or in taking a more active role in the organization is encouraged to attend for more information. 
 
Date: Tuesday, July 11
Location: Memorial Hall on 1225 Elm Street, Cincinnati, OH 45202
Time:  6 pm - 7:30pm

Don't Rock the Boat has been CANCELLED for Saturday, July 15, in light of high, unsafe water levels. We will work to reschedule this event, because we were really looking forward to hanging out with all of you! Stay tuned to our website, social media channels and newsletter for a future date. In the meantime, check out our events calendar for a few more upcoming volunteer events. 

 

Volunteer with us at Don't Rock the Boat!

Volunteer with us for our annual waterway clean-up event.  We're bringing back one of our tried and true favorites - Don't Rock the Boat!  On Saturday, July 15th we will hit Winton Woods to clean up trash along the lake's waterway.  If you haven't gone canoeing yet this summer, this will be the perfect opportunity to give back to the environment while meeting some new volunteers!   Admission to the park is waived for volunteers.  Just let the gate attendant know you're there to volunteer with Give Back Cincinnati, and you'll be granted entry.  All clean-up supplies, canoes, oars, and life vests will be provided to volunteers. We'll cool down and celebrate the success of the event with a happy hour afterwards at a local watering hole.  First round will be on us!  Date: Saturday, July 15 Time: 9am - 12pm Location: Winton Woods at 10245 Winton Rd, Cincinnati, OH 45231 [mc4wp_form id="8578"]

Drink Local 

In our upcoming Civic Engagement event‚ÄîDrink Local‚Äîwe‚Äôre riffing off the eat-local trend to celebrate Cincinnati‚Äôs great beverage scene. We will feature some of the lesser-known local breweries, but this event will be much more than just beer. We‚Äôre also targeting local coffee shops, juice bars, wineries, dairies, and more! It will be an expo-style event where attendees can walk around and learn about each participating business, talk to people involved, and try samples. We will also have experts speaking about why it‚Äôs important to drink local, and the impact these businesses have on our community. Participating Businesses:

post_title: Showing Community Matters in Lower Price Hill
post_content:
Volunteer and Show That Community Matters

Volunteer with us and show that community matters as we come together to help improve community spaces within Lower Price Hill.  We are partnering with Community Matters, a Lower Price Hill based nonprofit organization that strives to remove barriers to opportunity so that we can create a thriving community with our neighbors. As our fourth Hands On volunteer project of the year, we will work on site clean up, beautification, and improvement of community spaces. We will also setup a sewing workshop and picnic tables for the community along with cleaning up and transforming green space that is located throughout the area.  Wear clothes that you can do some hard work in!  The after party will be hosted at Lower Price Hill Pizza Co.  Details: Date: Saturday, September 23 Time: 9:00am - 1:30pm Location: Lower Price Hill - 2104 Saint Michael Street, Cincinnati, OH 45204 After party: Lower Price Hill Pizza Co.  [mc4wp_form id="8578"]

post_title: 2018 Leadership Event #1: The Who, What, Why & How of Give Back Cincinnati
2018 Leadership Event #1: The Who, What, Why & How of Give Back Cincinnati
post_content:
2018 Leadership Event #1: The Who, What, Why & How of Give Back Cincinnati

Give Back Cincinnati‚Äôs Leadership Committee invites you to attend the first leadership training session of 2018! During this super interactive event, we‚Äôll share more about who we are as an organization, what we do and why we make the choices we make, and how we execute our events. We'll also spend some time brainstorming future events that Cincinnati-area YPs will love. Whether you're already part of a committee or you're simply interested in figuring out where you fit in the organization, come learn about how you can be part of taking Give Back Cincinnati events to the next level.  Who Should Attend: Anyone who is currently involved or would like to be involved in a Give Back Cincinnati committee, including hands-on, interactive, civic engagement, and social events; Paint the Town, Fuel, Fall Feast, Cincinnati YP or Give Back Beyond; and executive board members.  When: Saturday, January 27 10 a.m. to 12:30 p.m., followed by networking at Brother‚Äôs Bar & Grill Where: Newport on the Levee Community Room A, located on the lower level next to Gameworks What‚Äôs on the Agenda: The Leadership Committee will supply breakfast and liquid gold (aka coffee). We‚Äôll then dive into GBC operations in three parts: Give Back Cincinnati 101, how to run a GBC event and future event ideas. After you provide some feedback, we‚Äôll head to Brother's Bar & Grill to continue the discussion and the getting-to-know-you.  What to Bring: You may want to take notes, so bring whatever device you are comfortable with (including good ol‚Äô fashioned pen & paper). What You‚Äôll Get: Other than the pride of being involved in Give Back Cincinnati? Following the event, we'll share our Nuts & Bolts and Culture guides to help you really dig into getting things done. Our goal is also to provide a forum for idea sharing, meeting your fellow GBCers and learning a few tricks for flawlessly executing GBC events. Questions: Please email Lauren.Doyle [at] givebackcincinnati.org if you have questions.

Back to School

 

We have reached our cap on the number of volunteers this project can accommodate.  Please look at our website for upcoming volunteer opportunities. 

Give Back Cincinnati will kick off 2018 with one of our tried and true favorite events, Back to School! This year, we are partnering with Education Matters in East Price Hill to help them spread some TLC across their satellite facility, including organizing and painting the facility. Let's set the scene: You're up on a ladder during Paint the Town, getting ready to cut in around a gutter, when you notice your paintbrush isn't, well, cutting it. It's dried up and stiff, and it looks like it's seen one too many buckets of paint. Frustrating, right?  We've all been there, and we agree. Over the years, Paint the Town has painted 523 houses all NO COST to homeowners, and our supplies have definitely seen their fair share of wear and tear. Put another way: Our supplies could use some "brushing up!" (See what we did there?!)  That's why we're hosting Pints to Paintbrushes at MadTree on Sunday, April 15. We are raising money to cover the costs of most important supplies: paintbrushes!  For your donation, you can enjoy a beer on us, home improvement-themed games, fun raffle prizes and, of course, help Paint the Town Cincinnati in the process. What a Sunday Funday! Tickets: Your $10 ticket includes one beer ticket, 5 game tickets, and your donation. There's also an option to make an additional donation when you purchase your ticket. Buy your ticket in advance or pay at the door -- it's your choice!  Location: MadTree Brewing The Oakley Room 3301 Madison Road Cincinnati, OH 45209 When:  Sunday, April 15, 2018 12-3 p.m.  Optional Donations: 
One more paintbrush, please! $5
I'd rather buy a roller + roller cover $15
I'll get the heavy-duty drop cloths $20
Sign me up for work gloves $25
What the heck, I'll buy a ladder! $30

How do you tackle difficult conversations? It starts with understanding three stories: yours, theirs and the ‚Äúsomewhere in-between.‚Äù And that‚Äôs exactly what we‚Äôll discuss in this leadership development session: Having Difficult Conversations. This second Leadership Development session of the year will help leaders better serve their committees, the Give Back Cincinnati organization and even their professional lives by sharing common scenarios that make leadership difficult‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs a team member who isn‚Äôt pulling their weight or another volunteer who makes collaboration challenging. We‚Äôll also provide tips on how to surface and solve these issues in a healthy, productive manner, followed by some hands-on training. Afterward, we'll head across the street to Listermann Brewery for an afterparty! Event Details Date:  Saturday, April 28 Time:  10 a.m. ‚Äì 12:30 p.m. Location: Smith Hall, Room 247 | Xavier University | 3743 Ledgewood Dr. | Cincinnati, OH 45207 Parking: A parking lot is available next to Smith Hall at the corner of Francis Xavier Way and Dana Avenue.
